content: acc. Aristotle (onomatism, doctrine of simple names), metaphor, like mimēsis, must come back (revient) to physis, to its truth and its presence: nature finds itself, its proper analogy, nature gives itself in metaphor, thus metaphor is a natural gift, a characteristic of genius > geniuses have more nature, more generosity, more seed; Derrida asks whether everything can be taken from me except the power to replace? can physis sow itself?

content: sun turns in metaphor, philosophical metaphor turns toward the sun, flower of rhetoric, un tournesol, heliotrope
linkedContent: sun turns in metaphor, philosophical metaphor turns toward the sun, flower of rhetoric, un tournesol, heliotrope

content: sun is the paradigm of sensory and of metaphor: it turns and hides; first because aisthēton, sensory, can always not present itself [sun set], and second because it is exactly w/ metaphor that sensory absents itself: thus all metaphor attempts to describe turning of the sun
linkedContent: sun is the paradigm of sensory and of metaphor: it turns and hides; first because aisthēton, sensory, can always not present itself [sun set], and second because it is exactly w/ metaphor that sensory absents itself: thus all metaphor attempts to describe turning of the sun

content: since sensory sun can never be known all metaphors will be im-proper to it
linkedContent: since sensory sun can never be known all metaphors will be im-proper to it

content: [exemplary nature of sun in relation to metaphor] if sun is always metaphorical, it has lustre [Mallarmé], is an artificial construction, always other than itself, emerging from itself (father, eye, seed, fire, egg) > via Du Marsais, the philosophical metaphor light of the spirit is a detour w/in (in sight of) reappropriation, presence, etc. (from Platonic eidos to Hegelian Idea), a trope, a borrowed dwelling (house) > here, light is one metaphor among metaphors, and borrowed dwelling, expropriation, becomes metaphor of metaphor
linkedContent: [exemplary nature of sun in relation to metaphor] if sun is always metaphorical, it has lustre [Mallarmé], is an artificial construction, always other than itself, emerging from itself (father, eye, seed, fire, egg) > via Du Marsais, the philosophical metaphor light of the spirit is a detour w/in (in sight of) reappropriation, presence, etc. (from Platonic eidos to Hegelian Idea), a trope, a borrowed dwelling (house) > here, light is one metaphor among metaphors, and borrowed dwelling, expropriation, becomes metaphor of metaphor

content: sun structures metaphorical space of philosophy, represents what is natural in philosophical language, makes possible oppositions (appearing/disappearing, visible/invisible, present/absent)
linkedContent: sun structures metaphorical space of philosophy, represents what is natural in philosophical language, makes possible oppositions (appearing/disappearing, visible/invisible, present/absent)

content: when metaphysics opposes formal/artificial language to a natural one, “natural” leads us back to physis as solar system, to a history of relationship earth/sun in system of perception
linkedContent: when metaphysics opposes formal/artificial language to a natural one, “natural” leads us back to physis as solar system, to a history of relationship earth/sun in system of perception

content: [Aristotle on obfuscation and lies re: metaphors, bad metaphors, and that which is worse than metaphors]
linkedContent: [Aristotle on obfuscation and lies re: metaphors, bad metaphors, and that which is worse than metaphors]

content: everything in discourse of metaphor, passing through sign eidos, articulated w/ analogy btwn intelligible (nous) and visible (sensory) sun
linkedContent: everything in discourse of metaphor, passing through sign eidos, articulated w/ analogy btwn intelligible (nous) and visible (sensory) sun

content: stratified reading [re: Idea in Plato, Hegel]: neither pure etymology, nor pure origin, neither homogenous continuum nor absolute synchronism or simple interiority of system to itself > simultaneous critique of transcendental history of philosophy & of systematic structures perfectly closed over their technical/synchronic manipulation (bodies of work identified acc. “proper name" of signature)
linkedContent: stratified reading [re: Idea in Plato, Hegel]: neither pure etymology, nor pure origin, neither homogenous continuum nor absolute synchronism or simple interiority of system to itself > simultaneous critique of transcendental history of philosophy & of systematic structures perfectly closed over their technical/synchronic manipulation (bodies of work identified acc. “proper name" of signature)

content: philosophy, as theory of metaphor, will have been a metaphor of theory > permits/provokes transformation of presence into self-presence
linkedContent: philosophy, as theory of metaphor, will have been a metaphor of theory > permits/provokes transformation of presence into self-presence

content: though Hegel’s system is irreducible to Plato’s, the word Idea bears a traditional burden that continues Plato’s system in Hegel’s
linkedContent: though Hegel’s system is irreducible to Plato’s, the word Idea bears a traditional burden that continues Plato’s system in Hegel’s

content: Fontanier on why we say light of reason and light of day
linkedContent: Fontanier on why we say light of reason and light of day

content: in response to Fontanier’s new “proper sense,” a violent catachresis, btwn figurative and primitive sense, Derrida says: when the middle is not a passageway of mediation btwn oppositions, the opposition is not pertinent > consequences are boundless
linkedContent: in response to Fontanier’s new “proper sense,” a violent catachresis, btwn figurative and primitive sense, Derrida says: when the middle is not a passageway of mediation btwn oppositions, the opposition is not pertinent > consequences are boundless

content: philosophical language, system of catachreses, “forced metaphors,” reveal original “ideas,” truth, by a twisting return toward already-there of meaning > revelation, unveiling
linkedContent: philosophical language, system of catachreses, “forced metaphors,” reveal original “ideas,” truth, by a twisting return toward already-there of meaning > revelation, unveiling

content: in classical rhetoric, were metaphor to receive its name from metaphysics, it would be the catachresis: a “nontrue metaphor,” retracing metaphor through its philosophical ghost
linkedContent: in classical rhetoric, were metaphor to receive its name from metaphysics, it would be the catachresis: a “nontrue metaphor,” retracing metaphor through its philosophical ghost

content: metaphor is less in philosophical text than philosophical text is in metaphor
linkedContent: metaphor is less in philosophical text than philosophical text is in metaphor

content: la métaphysique—relève de la métaphore [chapter title]
linkedContent: la métaphysique—relève de la métaphore [chapter title]

content: Bachelard: science seduced by metaphors, creates ‘spaces of configuration’ more metaphorical than real
linkedContent: Bachelard: science seduced by metaphors, creates ‘spaces of configuration’ more metaphorical than real

content: Bachelard: Descartes’ metaphysics of space, a metaphorics of the sponge
linkedContent: Bachelard: Descartes’ metaphysics of space, a metaphorics of the sponge

content: Bachelard: even in the domain of exact sciences our imagination is a sublimation [advocates rigor as a psychoanalysis of intuition]
linkedContent: Bachelard: even in the domain of exact sciences our imagination is a sublimation [advocates rigor as a psychoanalysis of intuition]

content: field of science draws from nonscientific schema, and philosophy imports scientific schema as vast reservoir of metaphors
linkedContent: field of science draws from nonscientific schema, and philosophy imports scientific schema as vast reservoir of metaphors

content: in life sciences, which demand critique of teleological judgment, we take the metaphor for the concept, use of animistic or (technical, social, cultural) analogy [pp. 258-63 via Bachelard, use of metaphor in science]
linkedContent: in life sciences, which demand critique of teleological judgment, we take the metaphor for the concept, use of animistic or (technical, social, cultural) analogy [pp. 258-63 via Bachelard, use of metaphor in science]

content: Nietzsche takes risk of continuity btwn metaphor & concept, describes metaphorical tissue of man as spider’s web, Derrida follows web, tissu, tisser, to weave, honey bees, Marx
linkedContent: Nietzsche takes risk of continuity btwn metaphor & concept, describes metaphorical tissue of man as spider’s web, Derrida follows web, tissu, tisser, to weave, honey bees, Marx

content: by placing metaphor en abyme, Nietzsche is responsible for the need to find a new distinction than that btwn metaphor and concept
linkedContent: by placing metaphor en abyme, Nietzsche is responsible for the need to find a new distinction than that btwn metaphor and concept

content: TN. Bass gives a good account of mettre en abyme alongside abîmer: the former an endless reflection (heraldic term, escutcheon and on), the latter the ruination or plunging into abyss > “figurative of ruination”: when distinction btwn reflected/reflecting falls apart
linkedContent: TN. Bass gives a good account of mettre en abyme alongside abîmer: the former an endless reflection (heraldic term, escutcheon and on), the latter the ruination or plunging into abyss > “figurative of ruination”: when distinction btwn reflected/reflecting falls apart

content: for Bachelard, the hidden (fire) is what demands metaphors, Derrida explains how this conceptualization, despite fact that Bachelard appeals to syntax, “a poetic mind is a syntax of metaphors,” still amounts to metaphor of the same > here, all metaphors have a semantic focal point, the hidden fire as life, nature
linkedContent: for Bachelard, the hidden (fire) is what demands metaphors, Derrida explains how this conceptualization, despite fact that Bachelard appeals to syntax, “a poetic mind is a syntax of metaphors,” still amounts to metaphor of the same > here, all metaphors have a semantic focal point, the hidden fire as life, nature

content: when syntax is subordinated to semantics in concept of metaphor, what else will be found than a return to the same, the sun, the light, same circle, the dominant metaphor of the group, heightened by its power of dissimulation, escaping mastery: God or Sun?
linkedContent: when syntax is subordinated to semantics in concept of metaphor, what else will be found than a return to the same, the sun, the light, same circle, the dominant metaphor of the group, heightened by its power of dissimulation, escaping mastery: God or Sun?

content: most invariable characteristic of concept of metaphor: unity/continuity of meaning dominates play of syntax, subordination of syntax
linkedContent: most invariable characteristic of concept of metaphor: unity/continuity of meaning dominates play of syntax, subordination of syntax

content: dominant metaphor, major signified of ontotheleogy: circle of the heliotrope
linkedContent: dominant metaphor, major signified of ontotheleogy: circle of the heliotrope

content: it is lumen naturale that allows Descartes to affirm his mind beyond all doubt, natural light constitutes the ether of thought > natural light proceeds from God and returns to God
linkedContent: it is lumen naturale that allows Descartes to affirm his mind beyond all doubt, natural light constitutes the ether of thought > natural light proceeds from God and returns to God

content: because metaphoric is plural from the start, it cannot escape syntax, it organizes its division w/in syntax, cannot be what it is except in erasing itself, indefinitely constructing its destruction
linkedContent: because metaphoric is plural from the start, it cannot escape syntax, it organizes its division w/in syntax, cannot be what it is except in erasing itself, indefinitely constructing its destruction

content: the East is where the sensible sun rises, the sun sets, is interiorized, in heart (eye) of the West
linkedContent: the East is where the sensible sun rises, the sun sets, is interiorized, in heart (eye) of the West

content: one true metaphor (no more true metaphor): but assured legibility of the proper [presence disappearing in its own radiance, hidden source of light]
linkedContent: one true metaphor (no more true metaphor): but assured legibility of the proper [presence disappearing in its own radiance, hidden source of light]

content: metaphor’s 2 courses [classic, deconstructive] of self-destruction [the 2nd self-destruction, the other self-destruction, resembles the former, can be taken for it]: 1. the relève of metaphor, interiorization, return to itself of the sun, summarize-interiorize-dialecticize-master-relever; metaphor is either a provisional loss, or that which, through detour, can return to the same, to a full language w/out syntax, pure nomination 2. disrupts hierarchy of syntax and semantics, no longer about extending or confirming a philosopheme, but unfolding it w/out limit, “wresting its [philosopheme’s] borders of propriety from it,” explode reassuring opposition metaphoric/proper: “supplement of a code which traverses its own field, endlessly displaces its closure, breaks its line, opens its circle, no ontology can reduce it”
linkedContent: metaphor’s 2 courses [classic, deconstructive] of self-destruction [the 2nd self-destruction, the other self-destruction, resembles the former, can be taken for it]: 1. the relève of metaphor, interiorization, return to itself of the sun, summarize-interiorize-dialecticize-master-relever; metaphor is either a provisional loss, or that which, through detour, can return to the same, to a full language w/out syntax, pure nomination 2. disrupts hierarchy of syntax and semantics, no longer about extending or confirming a philosopheme, but unfolding it w/out limit, “wresting its [philosopheme’s] borders of propriety from it,” explode reassuring opposition metaphoric/proper: “supplement of a code which traverses its own field, endlessly displaces its closure, breaks its line, opens its circle, no ontology can reduce it”

content: Rousseau: metaphysics used to be an instinct, became a science when it ceased to be good
linkedContent: Rousseau: metaphysics used to be an instinct, became a science when it ceased to be good

content: opposition of metaphoric and proper have never done anything but reflect and refer to each other in their radiance [deconstruction can explode this opposition]
linkedContent: opposition of metaphoric and proper have never done anything but reflect and refer to each other in their radiance [deconstruction can explode this opposition]

content: metaphor always carries its death w/in itself, this death is always the death of philosophy [but the genitive is double]
linkedContent: metaphor always carries its death w/in itself, this death is always the death of philosophy [but the genitive is double]
